ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: - The applications of mathematics and functions in the creation of biomedical signals and imaging.
Continuous and Discrete Signals and Images, Modeling Techniques, MATLAB and Simulink applications

This was a great class that connected what we learned in biomechanics, physics, and diffeq with physiological systems. You really do learn about signals as well as images. One of my favorite BME courses at Yale.

Knowledge: Mathematical Modeling of Various types of signals.

Skills: MATLAB, Machine Learning (minimally), image processing
I learnt about the fundamentals of signals and images in biomedical engineering and also how they are applied to real-life systems

- continuous and discrete linear systems analysis
- Fourier analysis and frequency response, signal features, learning, and noise filtering

We learned a lot about linear time-invariant systems, the frequency domain, and various transforms (Fourier, Laplace, filtering). We also did a lot of continuous and discrete convolution and applied it to modeling physiological systems. From the course, we generally learned how signals are generated and manipulated.

From this course, I learned about how to transform functions from the time domain to frequency domain and vice versa. This course also teaches you about how to work with signals and the basis of imaging, such as transforming 2D images.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
- Professors are keen on making sure to supplement the material with real-life application examples. 
- Professors are relatively clear in their content. 
- Very active and helpful TA's.
Overall, the class was good, but more practice problems applying the material taught in class would be even more helpful.

Sometimes it was hard to keep up in class when notes were pre-written. Would be nice to have those pre-written slides before class too so that we can write on them along with the prof instead of starting out behind. Good examples and demos in class!

Strengths: Even though signals are not intuitive at all, it's not a very hard class, the professors give a ton of hints about the exam and psets
Weaknesses: It is pretty boring at times, the lectures are not very engaging
Great professors -- they really care about their students and teaching the material.

the course was great but I wish the profs had set office hours instead of asking us to email them for availability. I am shy and never got round to doing that so I didnt really develop a relationship with the profs even though it was a relatively small class.
Examples in problem sets and class did not translate to material tested sometimes

Strength: Amazing professors, they really cared about our learning, made it easy to do so. TAs were also very accessible. Problem sets were long / challenging, but reasonable. The answer keys were always clear and posted in a timely fashion

Weakness: Poor audio quality on Professor Staib's mic :(
It was very hard to focus over zoom, this was a very hard class and it took me a while to focus in the class.

Strengths: 
PSETs are fairly short, straightforward, and super helpful for learning the material/studying for exams. Also, the TAs are wonderful.

Weaknesses:
Sometimes the lectures get dull and feel disconnected from anything applicable to bme. It would be nice to get a broader view of the material and why certain computational concepts are applicable/important.

The material is more on the dry side, which can make it hard to follow. Prof. Staib's lecture is mainly PowerPoints while Prof. Duncan's lecture is mainly written out notes. Having more examples on the material before the midterm would had been very helpful.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I don't believe there was much of a difference in the course from COVID to what it would have been like in the classroom. It was lecture based with review sessions every week which have been helpful.
The online format was successful for this class. Slides were shared for lectures, iPad writing allowed live note-taking, and the TAs provided very helpful discussion sections.

I wish there was more engagement during class. Sometimes the chat box was disabled, so we could not type questions. Since class is 75 min, maybe doing some polls to check for understanding could be leveraged.
Recorded lectures. That way we didn't have to go to them live.
The weekly sessions were very helpful.
Successful: Recorded lectures, TAs very accessible online

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This is a class you must take as a BME major but overall I do believe the class has been helpful.
Yes, I'd recommend to anyone interested in learning about signals and images.

Absolutely! Great course if you are interested in doing anything machine learning as well. It gets more interesting toward the end of the course as you use your foundational signal and image skills on real examples like heart modeling, etc.
I don't think so, unless you have to.
Yes, very interesting and applicable
This is a required major course, I would not take it if I didn't have to.
It's required for BME students, but I would not recommend the course. You will spend each lecture confused even though the material isn't too difficult.
You need to take the class if you're BME. Otherwise, the way the material is taught makes it hard to stay engaged.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
Live virtual lectures with one virtual discussion section (led by the TAs) each week
there were weekly sessions to go over material taught and for pset help
Recorded lecture
both live virtual lecture and recorded lecture
